(Sgd.15/8W51 H f B.M’s Consulate, MOSCAT 1st Deoeniber, 19^1 Dear Finance Department, In our accounts for the quarters ended June 1950 and September 1950 we credited you with the sums of Rs 1129/1/6 and Rs 835/11/- for the account of the Pakistan Government, These have now to be refunded to the Government of liuscat; but the Accountant General Pakistan Revenues,Karachi, is unable to trace having received such credits. Could you please let us have any details of how these monies were paid to the Accountant General which would enable him to identify these transactions ? Yours ever Muscat Consulate Finance Department, Foreign Office, LOUDON.1 3/8/94/. 1 . H. E. M’s C->nsulat9 and- Political Agency, MUSCAT . 29th July, 1951. Bj- 635/1V- and 1129/1/6, credited by the Muscat Government to the Pakistan Government Account with the Foreign Office, London, may be refunded to the Government of Muscat, so that the dues of Mr# Abdur- Kahman may be repaid by a cheque from the Sultan 1 s account with the Lloyd’s Bank at Karachi# 4# The payment of lea*e salary and pension contributions, recoverable from the Muscat Govt* on behaU of Abdur Hahman, may also please be authorised to be by a cheque in the same manner# ex. for Secretary to the A#G#0# in Baluchistan# % 'Copy, with compliments, to His Britannic Consul, Muscat, with reference to his letter No. 6/11/94/51 dated the 29th April 1951• Copy.with a copy enclosures, forwarded to Mr. Abdur- , Rahman. H.B.H'a Conaulate and Political Agency, MUSCAT . 24th May, 1951 y I have the honour to refer to your letter No. E-275/51 dated the 3rd May 1951 and to say that it will he difficult to get any further or revised certificate from the Muscat Government. 2. In the circumstances I would suggest that this Consulate letter should he sufficient to enable the Accountant General, Pakistan Revenues to issue a payment order for Mr. Abdur Rahman’s salary after the 8th July 1949. If that is not possible a draft copy of the precise certificate that is required may kindly he supplied, and an attempt will he made to get it. 3. I also suggest that Mr. Abdur Rahman f s claim for leave, pension and provident fund contributions, if any, should he expedited, so that th£* whole case can now he closed. I have the honour to he H. B.M f s Consul a Political Agent t Muscat. The Secretariat, QUSTTA. Secretary to the Agent to the Governor General in bITo: 3-275/51. From ; The Secretary to the Hon f ble the agent to the Governor General and Chief Commissioner in Baluchistan. To : His Majesty's Consul and Political Agent, Muscat • Dated Quetta, the ^ May, 1951. with reference to yoi^r letter Mo. 4/8/94/51, dated the 19th April 1^51, I have the honour to s*y that in this office letter of the 29th March 1^51, it intended that a revis ed Last Pay Certificate, may be issued in favour of Mr. Abdur—Gahman, after taking into account the leave salary from 3rd May to 16th June 1*>43 and joining time pay from 17th June to 8 th July li>4^, drawn and paid by the jovsrnment of *..uscat, after Jie issue of the original one. It is accordingly request*d th*at the. required revised Last Pay Certificate may kindly be issued at an early dat*. I have the honour to be, Sir, Your most obedient servant, If \ -7 Secretary to the \gent to the Governor General in Baluchistan if 1—6/8/94/51 H.B.yis Consulate and Political Aganoy, MUSCAT. 29th April, 1951. Mr. Abdur Rahman - ax-Admlnlatrator, Gaadur. Sir, Re fare nee your letter No. E-275/51-4 dated the 29th March 1951. 2. A copy of our letter No. 3/8/94/51 dated the 14th April 1951 to the Muscat Government and their reply No. 522/15-G dated the 24th April 1951 is forwarded herewith. 3. suggest that, as further payments will be due in respect of pension etc: contributions, you should take it up as a special case with the Pakistan Government and the Accountant Genexal Pakistan Revenues to refund the amount paid so far, and to agree to the full dues being paid by cheque from the Sultan's account with Lloyd's Bank in Karachi as suggested, otherwise further payments can only be made in the same manner in Indian Currency through the United Kingdom. I have the honour to be Sir, Tour obedient servant, Sd/- F.C.L. Chauncy. His Britannic Majesty's Consul, Muscat. Secretary to the Agent to the Governor General in Baluchistan, Baluchistan Secretariat, QUETTA . Copy to s- Minister for Foreign Affairs, MUSCAT . for informationSULTANATE OF MUSCAT & OMAN 15-G. MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS MUSCAT 24th April, 1951. Mr. Ahdur Rehrnan-ex Administrator Gwadur. Sir, ^ / I have the honour to refer to your letter No. 3/8/94/51, da ted the 14th April, 1951. 2. In view of the fact that the debt was contracted when the currency in use here and Pakistan currency were at pai^with onetenother,the Muscat Government does not feel obliged to setule the account in accordance with the new rate of exchange. 3. We have, however,no desire that Mr. Abdur Rehman should suffer in any way and,provided the Indian currency already credited is refunded,are prepared to pay the whole amount in Pakistan currency, either in cash or by means of a Cheque on Lloyds Bank,Karachi. I have the honour to be, Sir, Your obedient servant. Minister for For^igrTTCffairs. His Britannic Majesty’s Consul, Muscat. Tour cbedi^nt Servant# ilia Majesty fhe fliniatcr for Storeign Afiairs, Mueoat#No: 3-275/51-4* From; To : Kis Majesty 1 s Consul, Muscat* Dated Quatta, the 2-^ March, 1S51« Subject: Mr. Abdur-Kahman - Bx-Admlni strater Gv/adur. y In continuation of this administration letter No. B-275/51-B, dated the March, 1951, I have the honour to request that necessary last pay certificate shov/ing the date upto and for v/hitfi the payment of leave salary and joining time/Sas been made in favour of Mr* Abdur-Rahman may kindly be sent to this Administration at an early date. I have the honour to be, Sir, Your most obedient servant, for Secretary to the Agent to the neral in Baluchistan (o'°' /v/MCr 0 Nos E-275/51-B. From : The Secretary to the Hon r ble the Agent to the Governor General in Baluchistan* To s His Ma^ 0 sty f s Consul, Muscat. Dated Quetta, the March, 1951. Subject s Mr. Abdur-Rehman - Bx-Administrator Gowadur - dues of Sir, With reference to the correspondence ending with the British Consulate letter No. 20/8/94/50, dated the 9th September 1950, I have the honour to forward herewith a copy of a representation received from Mr. Abdur-Rehrcan in regard to the credits on account of his Transfer T.A. and pay and leave salary from 1st May to 8 th July 1949 in Indian Currency instead of Pakistani Currency and to request that, if thera is no objection, the payment of the dues of Mr. Abdur-Rehman may kindly be made in the Pakistani Currency and the difference on the above account credited to the Pakistan Government account with the Foreign Office London. 2 . The debit on account of leave and pension contributions recoverable on behalf of Mr. Abdur-Rehman will ba raided by the Accountant General Pakistan Revenues against the Government of Muscat shortly. i nave the honour to be, Sir, Your most obedient servant, for Secretary to the Agent to the Governor General in BaluchistanCopy of latter No. 593/51, dated 6-1-1951, from the Wazir Lasbela State, Bala, Camp Karachi to the Revenue Commission -er in Baluchistan, Quetta. Subjects Dues of ^r. Abdur Rahman Khan, ex. Administrator CrVfadur, Oman State. 0 With reference to your endost. No. 3-375/50, date* the 28th Sept. 1950, I have the honour to state that on being approached the Accountant General Pakistan Revenues, Karachi, has informed that they have received intimation about the adjustment of Rs. 835/11/- (Rs. Sight hundred thirty five -/ll/-) and R's. 1129/1/- (Rs. One thousand one hundred twenty nine -/l/-) vide letter No. AC.290-1-62/SHH dated November nil, I960, from the High Commissioner of Pakistan in U.K. Ha also informed me that the Kascat Govt, had credited the amounts inquestion in Indian currency. This would mean that when the payment is made to me in Pakistan currency, I will stand to lose about Rs. 600/- without any obvious fault of mine. These amounts are due to me when both the currencies Were at par. The devaluation came much later and if settlement of my dues had been made earlier I would not have lost this large sum. 2 . Un&ar cue above explained circumstances, I feel justified to approach you with the request that Muscat Govt, may be requested at an early date to pay me these amounts either in Pakistan currency or as an alternative credit the amounts with the firm Haji Musa Juma of Muscat who have got a branch in Bela, from where I can receive these amounts provided an Intimation is sent by the above firm to their branch at Bela for payment of these dues to me. . * 3 . In-view of the difficulty already experienced it will not he out of place to point-out here that the A.G.P.R* may be informed to bear the fact in mind when raising necessary debit against the Muscat Govt, on account of my leave and pension contribution. '*** *** >«*********

location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 21; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. A previous foliation sequence between ff 12-18, which is also circled, has been superseded and therefore crossed out.

mods.abstract: Following on from the previous file (IOR/R/15/6/287), this file relates to the Sultanate of Muscat and Oman's former Administrator at Gwadur [Gwadar], Abdur Rahman Qureshi, who was on deputation from Baluchistan from 1946 to 1949.The file concerns outstanding payments owed to Abdur Rahman, specifically those relating to his pay, leave salary, 'transfer travel allowance', leave and pension.Notable correspondents include the following: the Political Agent and Consul, Muscat; the Secretary to the Agent to the Governor General and Chief Commissioner in Baluchistan; the High Commission for Pakistan, London.
